headline: Troubles pensions scheme opens for applications
article: This video can not be played In separate IRA bomb attacks Jennifer McNern lost both her legs and Margaret Yeaman was blinded A pension scheme for people who were badly injured during the Troubles has opened for applications. The start of the Troubles Permanent Disablement Payment Scheme is more than a year behind schedule, having been the subject of political rows. To qualify, a person must have suffered a severe and permanent physical or psychological injury caused through no fault of their own during the Troubles. Recipients will receive annual payments of between Â£2,000 and Â£10,000. The UK government and the Northern Ireland Executive havelong been at odds about how the scheme will be funded, with the overall costs potentially topping Â£1.2bn over the next 20 to 30 years. The Troubles claimed more than 3,500 lives and it has been estimated that another 40,000 were injured Last year a judge ruled Stormont's Executive Office wasacting unlawfully in delaying the introduction of the scheme. He said the start of the scheme was being deliberately stymied in order to pressurise the government into funding it. He also determined there was an attempt by Deputy First Minister Michelle O'Neill to have the scheme's eligibility criteria changed, with her party, Sinn FÃ©in, having said the rules potentially discriminated against some republicans with Troubles-era convictions. Funding for the scheme has been agreed for this year, but Stormont ministers still want the government to provide extra cash to help cover future expenditure. Margaret Yeaman, who was blinded in an IRA bomb in Banbridge, County Down, in 1982, said it had been a "long, bumpy road" for her and others injured during the Troubles who have been waiting for the payments. "I'll not even say that we're getting it until I have it in my hand," she said. The level of payment through the scheme will depend on the severity of a victim's injuries Jennifer McNern described the payments as "recognition" of what she had been through since she lost both of her legs after an IRA bomb explosion in Belfast in 1972. "This is really an acknowledgement of the harm caused physically, psychologically and financially," she said. Executive must fund Troubles pension, court rules The victims' group, the Wave Trauma Centre, said the opening of the scheme was a "triumph for the courageous and determined campaigners who have fought for over a decade" for the payments. "At times it was desperately frustrating but they never lost their focus on gaining tangible recognition for all those like themselves who had been severely and permanently injured through no fault of their own," said the group's co-ordinator Alan McBride. "We'll also remember those who campaigned but didn't live long enough to see this day." The group Relatives For Justice said the qualification criteria for the pension should be extended. AndrÃ©e Murphy, its deputy director, welcomed the initiative but insisted modifications need to be considered. "It is very possible that a paramedic or a police officer or an eye-witness at a scene will be eligible for a payment and a loved-one who has suffered the deep psychological distress and trauma since then will not be eligible for this," she said. "That is going to feel unfair and we have to resolve it," she added. This video can not be played The roots of Northern Irelandâs Troubles lie deep in Irish history After a series of delays, the scheme was to have opened in June but Mr Justice McAlinden, who chairs the panel overseeing the awarding of the payments,pushed it back until the end of August. That final delay, he said, was to allow applicants to "familiarise themselves" with "complex" medical assessment guidance before making their submissions. He said he hopes that money will start being distributed to victims before the end of this year. In an interview with BBC News NI, he said he was confident that enough funding would be available for everyone entitled to payments, and he hoped the process would begin soon. The judge said: "I would hope that there would be a speedy turnaround for non-complex, relatively straight-forward cases. "We'll just have to see how we measure up to our goals but I would hope that, let's say, it will be within months as opposed to years for the vast majority of applicants to receive determinations from the board." Asked if this meant that the money would start being paid before the end of this year, he said: "Yes. I would hope so." "I'm not worried about the issue of funding," Mr Justice McAlinden told the BBC Asked about the provision of funding, Mr Justice McAlinden said there was still political "debate, discussion, disagreement as to where the funding will ultimately come from." But he added: "I have an undertaking, given in court, to the Court of Appeal that in terms of the role of the board, the payments that the board allocate and award, those payments will be met." The scheme covers violence related to the Troubles between 1966 and 2010, including incidents in Great Britain and Europe. Non-UK residents injured outside the UK cannot apply, such as victims of the Dublin and Monaghan bombings carried out by loyalists in 1974. After the death of a recipient, their spouse or carer will get the payments for a further 10 years. Welcoming the opening of the scheme, First Minister Paul Givan said the scheme would give people who had suffered as a result of the Troubles "the practical support and recognition that they deserve". Deputy First Minister Michelle O'Neill said it had been "a difficult and painful road for victims and survivors", and encouraged anyone who had suffered permanent physical or psychological disablement as a result of the conflict to make an application. Justice Minister Naomi Long said it was an important day for all victims and survivors, "but particularly for those who campaigned for this scheme with dignity and commitment for so long". headline: Transfer deadline day: All the reaction to the day's signings
article: Transfer window has closed Man Utd confirm return of club legend Cristiano Ronaldo from Juventus for 15m euros (Â£12.86m) Premier League clubs go into day having spent close to Â£1bn Odsonne Edouard completes Â£14m move from Celtic to Crystal Palace; Chelsea sign Atletico's Saul Niguez Arsenal sign Bologna defender Takehiro Tomiyasu; Spurs sign Barcelona defender Emerson for Â£25.75m Leeds complete Â£30m deal for Man Utd's Daniel James, Leicester sign Lookman on loan & Everton want Rondon Rennes' Eduardo Camavinga signs for Real Madrid , Griezmann signs for Atletico on loan Get involved - #bbcfootball or text 81111 (UK only - standard message rates apply) Shamoon Hafez and Emlyn Begley This live page is finished now - thanks for joining us all day - but if you're still hungry for football transfers... See every done deal today on our transfers page Check out BBC Radio 5 Live's Football Daily Recap on some of the top transfer stories today... Chelsea sign Atletico's Saul Arsenal sign Â£16m defender and loan out fringe players Atletico Madrid sign Griezmann Spurs sign Emerson and let Aurier go Leeds finally sign James Palace sign Â£14m Celtic striker When I moved countries to study journalism at university it wasn't so I could stay up all night in the hope that Barcelona announced the signing of Luuk de Jong on loan from Sevilla. So I think we're going to wrap it up now. It can be a nice surprise for us all tomorrow morning. We haven't had confirmation about Barcelona signing Sevilla striker Luuk de Jong yet. Spanish football journalist Andy West is obviously excited about watching Barca's new-look front line. Allow Twitter content? This article contains content provided by Twitter. We ask for your permission before anything is loaded, as they may be using cookies and other technologies. You may want to readTwitterâs cookie policy,externalandprivacy policy,externalbefore accepting. To view this content chooseâaccept and continueâ. Not the best text we've ever had to be honest. But it's late so we're all getting tired. Text 81111 (standard network charges apply) A Anon That wasn't a hint that Erling Braut Haaland is going to PSV Eindhoven for Â£250m. Still 31,000 of you reading this live text. Good perseverance. We're not sure if anything else is on the way now. Although you never know with this window. My apologies if you sign off now I've said that and Erling Braut Haaland joins PSV Eindhoven for Â£250m or something. Imagine how annoying it would be if a team signed two players from another team - but announced them a few minutes apart? In unrelated news, Fulham have signed Watford midfielder Nathaniel Chalobah, 26, for an undisclosed fee. Ten minutes ago they signed Watford's Domingos Quina on loan. Manchester United It seems like Edinson Cavani is happy to stay and fight for his place in Manchester United's talent-rich attacking line if his Instagram story is anything to go by. More good news for United fans. Clinton MorrisonFormer Republic of Ireland striker on BBC Radio 5 Live Romelu Lukaku will be a brilliant signing, he makes Chelsea title contenders. He'll easily get over 20 goals, and Jack Grealish will be a great signing for City as well Can't football administrators just go to bed now? Fulham have signed Portuguese forward Domingos Quina, 21, on a season-long loan from Watford - with the option to make it permanent. Allow Twitter content? This article contains content provided by Twitter. We ask for your permission before anything is loaded, as they may be using cookies and other technologies. You may want to readTwitterâs cookie policy,externalandprivacy policy,externalbefore accepting. To view this content chooseâaccept and continueâ. When Barcelona signed Antoine Griezmann in 2019, there were doubts about how he would gel with Lionel Messi and Luis Suarez. I wonder what odds you'd have got on none of them playing for Barcelona by 1 September 2021. Griezmann and Suarez link up again at Atleti... #bbcfootball or text 81111 (UK only - standard message rates apply) Clubs have weeks, or months, to sort out transfers - yet most are left to the last minute. Can I offer my services to do a bit of organisational skills training for them? A one day course should do it. As they all seem pretty flush I will bump up my rate though. Kenny, Edinburgh Barcelona say Atletico Madrid will pay all of Antoine Griezmann's wages. That will presumably help Barca register their new players. They add that there is a "compulsory permanent transfer clause" too. Griezmann is the 11th player to leave financially-struggling Barcelona this summer, including Lionel Messi - and the third today. Right-back Emerson Royal joined Tottenham for Â£25.8m and teenage midfielder Ilaix Moriba moved to RB Leipzig for Â£13.7m. Atletico Madrid say the Antoine Griezmann signing from Barcelona is a loan for one season with the option of another. Two years ago the France international made the move the other way after Barca paid his Â£107m buyout clause. But the 30-year-old's time at the Nou Camp has been a disappointment as he scored 35 goals in 102 games and only won the Copa del Rey. He has never won La Liga, joining Atletico Madrid in 2014, Barcelona in 2019 and Atleti now - every time just after his new side had won the league. Atletico Madrid re-sign forward Antoine Griezmann from Barcelona The biggest move of the day and a shock one. France World Cup winner Antoine Griezmann has rejoined Atletico Madrid from Barcelona on a season-long loan deal. As that guy says 'here we go'... Interesting.La Liga's transfers page,externalalready has Antoine Griezmann to Atletico. Done deal? The big one we're still waiting on is Atletico Madrid signing Antoine Griezmann from Barcelona. There is also some talk Barca might sign Sevilla striker Luuk de Jong as a replacement. De Jong and Martin Braithwaite up front. What a dream. We told you earlier that Swansea were trying to sign Brentford winger Tariqe Fosu on a season-long loan. Well that has fallen through so the Ghana international, 25, is likely to stay with the Premier League side. Good news for people who inexplicably named their fantasy football team after Fosu.
